questions: Initially, a conductive dielectric sphere with a free charge of 0 is placed in a vacuum. It is known that the radius of the conducting sphere is $R$, its relative permittivity is $\varepsilon_{r}$, and its conductivity is $\sigma$. At the moment $t=0$, a uniform external field ${{\vec{E}}_{0}}$ is applied around the conducting sphere, and free charge begins to accumulate on the surface of the conductor. The permittivity of the vacuum is $\varepsilon_0$. Try to determine the total Joule heat generated by the system from the initial state to the steady state.
solutions:
Considering the moment when $\ell\to0^{+}$, the polarization properties of the dielectric are prioritized over the conductive properties. At this time, the potential distribution is equivalent to the polarization of a dielectric sphere with a relative dielectric constant of $\varepsilon_{\mathsf{r}}$ in a uniform external field.
$$
\sigma_{i}=P\cos\theta
$$

Further,

$$
\bar{P}=(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}-1)\varepsilon_{0}\left(E_{0}-\frac{P}{3\varepsilon_{0}}\right)
$$

Solving,

$$
P=3\varepsilon_{0}\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}
$$

Effective electric dipole outside the sphere,

$$
\mathscr{P}=\frac{4}{3}\pi\mathscr{R}^{3}P=\frac{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}(\varepsilon_{r}-1)}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}R^{3}
$$

Solving,

$$
U_{i n.}(t\rightarrow0^{+})=-{\frac{3}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}}E_{0}r\cos\theta
$$

$$
\zeta_{c x}(t\rightarrow0^{+})=-E_{0}r\cos\theta+\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}\frac{R^{3}}{r^{2}}\cos\theta
$$

Considering the moment when it reaches a steady state, the conductive dielectric sphere fully exhibits the properties of an ideal conductor $(\varepsilon_{r}\to+\infty)$, solving,

$$
\bar{U}_{i n}(t;\to\infty)=0
$$

$$
U_{\mathrm{cx}}(t\rightarrow\infty)=-E_{0}\tau\cos\theta+E_{0}\frac{R^{3}}{r^{2}}\cos\theta
$$

Considering the moment $t$, when the interior of the conductive dielectric sphere is free from charge, its free charges should be distributed sinusoidally on the surface, assuming the spatial potential distribution satisfies,

$$
U=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{-E_{0}r\cos\theta+A(t)\frac{\cos\theta}{r^{2}},}&{\mathrm{if~}R<r} \\ {-E_{0}r\cos\theta+B(t)r\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}0<r<R}\end{array}\right.
$$

Considering the continuity of potential on $\mathcal{R}$,

$$
-E_{0}R\cos{\theta}+A(t)\frac{\cos{\theta}}{R^{2}}=-E_{0}R\cos{\theta}+B(t)R\cos{\theta}
$$

Simplifying to get,

$$
B(t)=A(t)\frac{1}{R^{3}}
$$

Further considering the distribution of space electric field along the $\hat{r}$ direction,

$$
E_{\mathrm{r}}=-\frac{\partial U}{\partial r}=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{E_{0}\cos\theta+A(t)\frac{2\cos\theta}{r^{3}},}&{\mathrm{if~}R<r} \\ {E_{0}\cos\theta-B(t)\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}0<r<R}\end{array}\right.
$$

Considering the charging process at the surface,

$$
j_{n}=\sigma\vec{E}_{i n}\cdot\hat{r}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{f}}{\mathrm{d}t}
$$

Where,

$$
\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{f}=(\vec{D}_{e x}-\vec{D}_{i n})\cdot\boldsymbol{\hat{r}}=(\varepsilon_{0}\vec{E}_{c x}-\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon_{r}\vec{E}_{i n})\cdot\boldsymbol{\hat{r}}
$$

Substituting into the previous equation,

$$
\sigma B(t)+\varepsilon_{0}\frac{2}{R^{3}}\frac{\mathrm{d}A(t)}{\mathrm{d}t}+\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon_{r}\frac{\mathrm{d}B(t)}{\mathrm{d}t}=0
$$

Further considering the previous equation,

$$
\sigma\left(B(t)-E_{0}\right)+\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})\frac{\mathrm{d}B(t)}{\mathrm{d}t}=0
$$

Considering the initial condition,

$$
B(t\rightarrow0^{+})=\frac{\varepsilon_{r}-1}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}
$$

Solving,

$$
B(t)=E_{0}-\frac{3}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}E_{0}e^{-\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})}t}
$$

Further obtaining the spatial potential distribution,

$$
\begin{array}{r}{U=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{-E_{0}r\cos\theta+\left(1-\frac{3}{\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}}+2}e^{-\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_{0}(2+\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}})}t}\right)E_{0}\frac{R^{3}}{r^{2}}\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}R<r} \\ {-\frac{3}{\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}}+2}e^{-\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_{0}(2+\epsilon_{\mathrm{r}})}t}E_{0}r\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}0<r<R}\end{array}\right.}\end{array}
$$

Utilizing the previous equation, it is easy to obtain the radial component distribution of the electric displacement vector inside and outside the surface of the conductive dielectric sphere,

$$
D_{\mathsf{r}}=\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{3\varepsilon_{0}\left[1-\frac{2}{\epsilon_{r}+2}e^{-\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})}t}\right]E_{0}\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}r\to R^{+}} \\ {-\frac{3\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}}{\varepsilon_{r}+2}e^{-\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})}t}E_{0}\cos\theta,}&{\mathrm{if~}r\to R^{-}}\end{array}\right.
$$

Obtaining the surface free charge distribution,

$$
\sigma_{f}=(\overrightarrow{\vec{D}}_{e x}-\overrightarrow{\vec{D}}_{i n})\cdot\hat{r}=3\epsilon_{0}\left(1-e^{-\frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_{0}(2+\epsilon_{r})}t}\right)E_{0}\cos\theta
$$

Considering the Joule heat theorem, the Joule heat power density inside the conductive dielectric sphere is,

$$
P_{J}=\stackrel{\rightarrow}{\vec{j}}\cdot\vec{E}_{i n}^{\prime}=\frac{9\sigma}{(\varepsilon_{r}+2)^{2}}e^{-2\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})}t}E_{0}^{2}
$$

Total Joule heat power in the entire space,

$$
W_{J}=\underbrace{P_{J}\mathrm{d}V}_{V_{\Theta\:\sharp\wedge\Theta}}=\frac{12\pi\sigma}{(\varepsilon_{r}+2)^{2}}e^{-2\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})}t}R^{3}E_{0}^{2}
$$

Further obtaining the total Joule heat,

$$
Q_{t o t}=\int_{0}^{\infty}W_{J}\mathrm{d}t=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{12\pi\sigma}{(\varepsilon_{r}+2)^{2}}e^{-2\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}(2+\varepsilon_{r})}t}R^{3}E_{0}^{2}\mathrm{d}t=\frac{6\pi\varepsilon_{0}}{(\varepsilon_{r}+2)}R^{3}E_{0}^{2}
$$
improved_solutions:
The total Joule heat generated from the initial state to the steady state is determined by integrating the power dissipation due to the current density inside the conductive dielectric sphere. The sphere has radius \(R\), relative permittivity \(\varepsilon_r\), conductivity \(\sigma\), and is placed in a uniform external field \(\vec{E}_0\) at \(t=0\). The vacuum permittivity is \(\varepsilon_0\).

### Approach
1. **Initial Electric Field Inside the Sphere**: At \(t=0+\), immediately after the external field is applied, the sphere behaves as a dielectric with no free charge movement yet. The electric field inside a dielectric sphere in a uniform external field \(\vec{E}_0\) is uniform and given by:
   \[
   \vec{E}_{\text{in}}(0+) = \frac{3}{\varepsilon_r + 2} \vec{E}_0
   \]

2. **Decay of the Electric Field**: Due to the finite conductivity \(\sigma\), free charges move and accumulate on the surface, causing the electric field inside the sphere to decay exponentially to zero in the steady state. The decay time constant is the relaxation time:
   \[
   \tau = \frac{\varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r}{\sigma}
   \]
   The electric field inside the sphere as a function of time is:
   \[
   \vec{E}(t) = \frac{3}{\varepsilon_r + 2} \vec{E}_0 e^{-t / \tau}
   \]

3. **Joule Heat Power Density**: The power dissipated per unit volume due to Joule heating is given by:
   \[
   \frac{dQ}{dV dt} = \sigma [E(t)]^2
   \]
   Substituting the expression for \(E(t)\):
   \[
   \frac{dQ}{dV dt} = \sigma \left( \frac{3}{\varepsilon_r + 2} \right)^2 E_0^2 e^{-2t / \tau}
   \]

4. **Total Joule Heat**: Integrate the power density over time and the volume of the sphere:
   \[
   Q = \int_V dV \int_0^\infty \sigma \left( \frac{3}{\varepsilon_r + 2} \right)^2 E_0^2 e^{-2t / \tau}  dt
   \]
   The volume integral is over the sphere of radius \(R\):
   \[
   \int_V dV = \frac{4}{3} \pi R^3
   \]
   The time integral is:
   \[
   \int_0^\infty e^{-2t / \tau}  dt = \frac{\tau}{2}
   \]
   Substituting \(\tau = \varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r / \sigma\):
   \[
   \int_0^\infty e^{-2t / \tau}  dt = \frac{\varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r}{2 \sigma}
   \]

5. **Combine and Simplify**: Substitute the integrals and simplify:
   \[
   Q = \sigma \left( \frac{3}{\varepsilon_r + 2} \right)^2 E_0^2 \cdot \frac{4}{3} \pi R^3 \cdot \frac{\varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r}{2 \sigma}
   \]
   The \(\sigma\) cancels:
   \[
   Q = \left( \frac{9}{(\varepsilon_r + 2)^2} \right) E_0^2 \cdot \frac{4}{3} \pi R^3 \cdot \frac{\varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r}{2}
   \]
   Simplify further:
   \[
   Q = \frac{9 \cdot 4 \pi R^3 \varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r E_0^2}{3 \cdot 2 (\varepsilon_r + 2)^2} = \frac{36 \pi R^3 \varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r E_0^2}{6 (\varepsilon_r + 2)^2} = \frac{6 \pi \varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r R^3 E_0^2}{(\varepsilon_r + 2)^2}
   \]

### Final Answer
The total Joule heat generated from the initial state to the steady state is:
\[
\boxed{\dfrac{6\pi \varepsilon_{0} \varepsilon_{r} R^{3} E_{0}^{2}}{\left(\varepsilon_{r} + 2\right)^{2}}}
\]

questions:
It is often observed that when a puppy gets wet, it will vigorously shake its body, and with just a few quick shakes, it can rid itself of most of the water. In fact, the loose skin and longer fur of dogs provide a biological rationale for this behavior. However, this might drive you crazy when you are giving the dog a bath!

To address this, consider the following kinematics problem: treat the puppy as a sphere with radius $R$ in a uniform gravitational field with gravity $g$. The center of the sphere is suspended at a height $H>R$ above the ground. Establish a Cartesian coordinate system where the $z$-axis is vertical, the ground is at $z=0$, and the sphere's center is located at $(0,0,H)$. The sphere rotates uniformly with an angular velocity vector along the $x$ direction, and the magnitude is $\omega$. Consider a droplet of water being flung off the surface of the sphere, and then follows a trajectory under the influence of gravity.

If the angular velocity is too small, water droplets cannot be flung off the top, so there's a minimum angular velocity $\omega_{1}$.

When the angular velocity $\omega>\omega_{1}$, there is still a region on the sphere where droplets cannot be normally flung off. Find the equation of the curve projecting the boundary of this region onto the $xy$-plane (express this as an equation involving $y^2$ in terms of $x$).
solutions:
Take the $x$-axis as the polar axis, and the $z$-axis as the reference axis for the azimuthal angle, i.e.:  

$$
\begin{aligned}{x}&={R\cos{\theta}}\\ {y}&={R\sin{\theta}\sin{\varphi}}\\{z}&={H+R\sin{\theta}\cos{\varphi}}\end{aligned}
$$  

Then the velocity of the circular motion at the point:  

$$
v=\omega r=\omega R\sin\theta
$$  

The radius of curvature of the parabolic path of the water droplet follows:  

$$
g\cos\varphi={\frac{v^{2}}{\rho}}
$$  

In order to eject the water drop, it needs to satisfy:  

$$
\rho>r=R\sin\theta
$$  

Setting the equality gives the boundary condition:  

$$
\omega^{2}R\sin\theta=g\cos\varphi
$$  

Expressing $\theta, \varphi$ in terms of $x, y$ and simplifying:  

$$
\boxed{y^{2}=\frac{\omega^{4}}{g^{2}}(R^{2}-x^{2})\left(x^{2}-R^{2}+\frac{g^{2}}{\omega^{4}}\right)}
$$
improved_solutions:
To solve this problem, consider a water droplet on the surface of a sphere of radius \(R\) centered at \((0, 0, H)\) in a uniform gravitational field \(g\) downward. The sphere rotates uniformly with angular velocity \(\omega\) about the \(x\)-axis. The condition for a droplet to be flung off is derived using the effective gravity in the rotating frame, where the effective acceleration \(\mathbf{g}_{\text{eff}}\) is the sum of gravitational acceleration and centrifugal acceleration.

The effective acceleration \(\mathbf{g}_{\text{eff}}\) at a point \((x, y, z)\) is:
\[
\mathbf{g}_{\text{eff}} = \left( 0, \omega^2 y, \omega^2 (z - H) - g \right).
\]
The radial unit vector outward from the sphere's center is:
\[
\hat{\mathbf{r}} = \left( \frac{x}{R}, \frac{y}{R}, \frac{z - H}{R} \right).
\]
The radial component of \(\mathbf{g}_{\text{eff}}\) is:
\[
\mathbf{g}_{\text{eff}} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{r}} = \frac{1}{R} \left[ \omega^2 y^2 + \omega^2 (z - H)^2 - g (z - H) \right].
\]
Using the sphere equation \(x^2 + y^2 + (z - H)^2 = R^2\), substitute \(y^2 + (z - H)^2 = R^2 - x^2\):
\[
\mathbf{g}_{\text{eff}} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{r}} = \frac{1}{R} \left[ \omega^2 (R^2 - x^2) - g (z - H) \right].
\]
The droplet flies off when \(\mathbf{g}_{\text{eff}} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{r}} > 0\). Thus, it remains attached when:
\[
\omega^2 (R^2 - x^2) - g (z - H) \leq 0.
\]
The boundary occurs at equality:
\[
\omega^2 (R^2 - x^2) = g (z - H).
\]
For the upper hemisphere (\(z - H > 0\)), substitute \(z - H = \sqrt{R^2 - x^2 - y^2}\):
\[
\omega^2 (R^2 - x^2) = g \sqrt{R^2 - x^2 - y^2}.
\]
Solving for \(y^2\):
\[
\sqrt{R^2 - x^2 - y^2} = \frac{\omega^2 (R^2 - x^2)}{g}.
\]
Square both sides:
\[
R^2 - x^2 - y^2 = \left( \frac{\omega^2 (R^2 - x^2)}{g} \right)^2.
\]
Rearrange to solve for \(y^2\):
\[
y^2 = R^2 - x^2 - \frac{\omega^4}{g^2} (R^2 - x^2)^2.
\]
Factor:
\[
y^2 = (R^2 - x^2) \left( 1 - \frac{\omega^4}{g^2} (R^2 - x^2) \right).
\]
This equation defines the projection of the boundary curve onto the \(xy\)-plane, giving \(y^2\) as a function of \(x\). The region where droplets cannot be flung off corresponds to points satisfying the inequality \(\omega^2 (R^2 - x^2) \leq g (z - H)\), and this boundary curve separates that region.

### Final Answer
The equation of the curve projecting the boundary onto the \(xy\)-plane is:
\[
\boxed{y^{2} = (R^{2} - x^{2}) \left( 1 - \frac{\omega^{4}}{g^{2}} (R^{2} - x^{2}) \right)}
\]

questions:
Building the experimental setup for diffraction with a steel ruler: Establish a spatial Cartesian coordinate system, with the positive $x$ direction pointing vertically downward and the positive $z$ direction pointing perpendicularly towards the wall. The angle between the steel ruler and the $z$-axis in the horizontal plane is $\phi$, and the angle between the steel ruler and the horizontal plane is $\xi$. A laser is directed along the positive $z$ direction onto the surface of the steel ruler, with the horizontal distance from the point of contact to the wall being $L$. The graduations on the steel ruler are evenly distributed with a spacing of $d$, oriented perpendicular to the direction of the ruler.

By considering the wave vector continuous along the direction of the scale markings, one can derive the equation of the curve where the diffraction pattern appears (general property); by considering the strong interference between the graduations, one can determine the locations of the primary maxima in the diffraction pattern (specific property).

For simplicity, assume the steel ruler is completely horizontal, setting $\xi=0$. Find: the spacing of the primary maxima near the zeroth-order maximum $\Delta y$.
solutions:
Let the coordinates of the diffraction point be $(x,y)$, we can derive the incident wave vector and the reflected wave vector  

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{c}{\displaystyle\boldsymbol{k}=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}\hat{\boldsymbol{z}}}\ {\displaystyle\boldsymbol{k}^{\prime}=\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}\frac{x\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}+y\hat{\boldsymbol{y}}+L\hat{\boldsymbol{z}}}{\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+L^{2}}}}\end{array}\right.
$$  

The wave vector is continuous along the direction of the scale mark  

$$
({\pmb k}^{\prime}-{\pmb k})\cdot{\widehat{\pmb x}}=0
$$  

This yields  

$$
x=0
$$  

The interference between scales is extremely strong (assume the order is $n$)  

$$
(k^{\prime}-k)\cdot d(\sin\phi\widehat{\pmb{y}}+\cos\phi\widehat{\pmb{z}})=2n\pi
$$  

Solving, we obtain  

$$
(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}x^{2}+\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}-\sin\phi^{2}\right]y^{2}-2\sin\phi\cos\phi L y+\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d})^{2}+2\frac{n\lambda}{d}\cos\phi\right]L^{2}=0
$$   

The solution for $y$ is  

$$
y_{n}=\frac{\sin\phi\cos\phi+\sqrt{\sin\phi^{2}\cos\phi^{2}-\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}-\sin\phi^{2}\right]\left[(\frac{n\lambda}{d})^{2}+2\frac{n\lambda}{d}\cos\phi\right]}}{(\frac{n\lambda}{d}+\cos\phi)^{2}-\sin\phi^{2}}L
$$  

According to the problem statement  

$$
\frac{n\lambda}{d}\ll1
$$   

Then  

$$
y_{n}\approx\tan2\phi L-\frac{1+\tan2\phi^{2}}{\sin\phi}\frac{n\lambda}{d}L
$$  

The difference in $y$ is  

$$
\Delta y=\frac{1+\tan2\phi^{2}}{\sin\phi}\frac{\lambda L}{d}
$$
improved_solutions:
To determine the spacing of the primary maxima near the zeroth-order maximum, \(\Delta y\), for the diffraction pattern produced by a steel ruler with graduations, the setup involves a laser incident along the positive \(z\)-direction, and the ruler is oriented horizontally (\(\xi = 0\)) at an angle \(\phi\) to the \(z\)-axis in the horizontal plane (\(y\)-\(z\) plane). The graduations are perpendicular to the ruler's length, spaced evenly with spacing \(d\), and oriented parallel to the \(x\)-axis (vertical direction). The wall is at a distance \(L\) along the \(z\)-axis from the point of contact.

### Coordinate System and Grating Properties
- The coordinate system has \(x\) vertically downward, \(z\) perpendicular toward the wall, and \(y\) horizontal.
- With \(\xi = 0\), the ruler is horizontal, lying in a plane spanned by vectors \((1, 0, 0)\) (along \(x\)) and \((0, \sin\phi, \cos\phi)\) (along the ruler's length).
- The graduations are parallel to the \(x\)-axis, so the direction of the scale markings is along \(x\).
- The vector between adjacent graduations is \(\vec{a} = (0, d \sin\phi, d \cos\phi)\), so the grating periodicity is along the direction \((0, \sin\phi, \cos\phi)\).

### Incident and Diffracted Waves
- The incident laser wave vector is \(\vec{k}_i = (0, 0, k)\) with \(k = 2\pi / \lambda\), propagating along the \(+z\)-direction.
- Due to the grating's invariance in the \(x\)-direction (parallel to the grooves), the \(x\)-component of the diffracted wave vector is conserved: \(k_x = 0\).
- The diffracted wave vector \(\vec{k}_d = (0, k_y, k_z)\) satisfies \(k_y^2 + k_z^2 = k^2\).

### Grating Equation
The condition for constructive interference (primary maxima) of order \(m\) is:
\[
(\vec{k}_d - \vec{k}_i) \cdot \vec{a} = m \cdot 2\pi
\]
Substituting \(\vec{k}_i\) and \(\vec{a}\):
\[
[(0, k_y, k_z) - (0, 0, k)] \cdot (0, d \sin\phi, d \cos\phi) = m \cdot 2\pi
\]
\[
(0, k_y, k_z - k) \cdot (0, d \sin\phi, d \cos\phi) = m \cdot 2\pi
\]
\[
k_y \cdot d \sin\phi + (k_z - k) \cdot d \cos\phi = m \cdot 2\pi
\]
\[
d [k_y \sin\phi + (k_z - k) \cos\phi] = m \cdot 2\pi
\]
\[
k_y \sin\phi + (k_z - k) \cos\phi = m \cdot \frac{2\pi}{d} \quad (1)
\]

### Diffraction Pattern on the Wall
The wall is at \(z = L\). For a point \((0, y, L)\) on the wall, the direction vector is \((0, y, L)\). In the far field (\(L\) large), the diffracted wave vector components are:
\[
k_y = k \frac{y}{r}, \quad k_z = k \frac{L}{r}, \quad \text{where} \quad r = \sqrt{y^2 + L^2}
\]
Substitute into equation (1):
\[
k \frac{y}{r} \sin\phi + \left( k \frac{L}{r} - k \right) \cos\phi = m \cdot \frac{2\pi}{d}
\]
\[
k \left[ \frac{y \sin\phi}{r} + \left( \frac{L}{r} - 1 \right) \cos\phi \right] = m \cdot \frac{2\pi}{d} \quad (2)
\]

### Near Zeroth-Order Maximum (\(y \ll L\))
Near \(y = 0\), which corresponds to the zeroth-order maximum (\(m = 0\)), \(r \approx L\) for small \(y\). Equation (2) simplifies to:
\[
k \left[ \frac{y \sin\phi}{L} + \left( \frac{L}{L} - 1 \right) \cos\phi \right] = m \cdot \frac{2\pi}{d}
\]
\[
k \left[ \frac{y \sin\phi}{L} + (1 - 1) \cos\phi \right] = m \cdot \frac{2\pi}{d}
\]
\[
k \frac{y \sin\phi}{L} = m \cdot \frac{2\pi}{d}
\]
Solve for \(y\):
\[
y = \frac{m \cdot 2\pi L}{k d \sin\phi}
\]
Since \(k = 2\pi / \lambda\):
\[
y = \frac{m \cdot 2\pi L}{(2\pi / \lambda) d \sin\phi} = \frac{m L \lambda}{d \sin\phi}
\]
Thus, the position of the \(m\)-th order maximum is approximately:
\[
y_m \approx \frac{m L \lambda}{d \sin\phi}
\]

### Spacing Between Adjacent Maxima
The spacing \(\Delta y\) between adjacent primary maxima (e.g., between orders \(m\) and \(m+1\)) is:
\[
\Delta y = y_{m+1} - y_m = \frac{(m+1) L \lambda}{d \sin\phi} - \frac{m L \lambda}{d \sin\phi} = \frac{L \lambda}{d \sin\phi}
\]
This spacing is constant near the zeroth-order maximum (\(y = 0\)) and valid for small diffraction angles (\(y \ll L\)) and \(\phi\) not too small.

### Final Answer
The spacing of the primary maxima near the zeroth-order maximum is:
\[
\boxed{\Delta y = \dfrac{L \lambda}{d \sin \phi}}
\]

questions:
The interference phenomenon in variable refractive index systems is a new issue of concern in the field of optics in recent years. There is a thin film of non-dispersive variable refractive index medium with a constant thickness \(d\), where the refractive index within the film changes linearly with the distance from the film's surface. The refractive index at the lower surface is \(n_a\), and at the upper surface is \(n_b > n_a\). A beam of parallel light enters the film from the lower surface at an incident angle \(i\). Taking the incident point as the origin, the positive direction of the \(x\)-axis is along the lower surface of the film to the right, and the positive direction of the \(y\)-axis is perpendicular to the film surface upward.

If the incident light is monochromatic light with wavelength \(\lambda\), and the refractive index of air for this wavelength of light is \(n_0 = 1\), the distance between the incident points of two adjacent beams of incident light is \(2S\). The incident point of the first beam on the lower surface is denoted as Q, and the point from which it exits from the lower surface again after its first reflection from the upper surface is denoted as P, with OP = \(2S\). It is important to note that \(S\) is unknown and can be determined through other physical quantities; the final answer should not contain \(S\). Ignoring the phase change caused by reflection, find the phase difference \(\varphi\) between the two beams of light.
solutions:
The phase difference is \(\varphi = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda} \Delta L\), where \(\Delta L = L - L_0\).
\(L\) is the total optical path from the incident point Q through reflection to the exit point P in the medium.
\(L_0 = 2S \sin i\) is the optical path difference in air for two adjacent incident beams, which can also be understood as: if the light travels a horizontal distance \(2S\) in air (with a refractive index of 1), it is the projection of the optical path along the direction parallel to the incident light.
This definition of \(\Delta L\) describes the additional optical path difference caused by light traveling in the medium relative to traveling the same equivalent distance in air, which is often used to describe the formation of interference patterns.

1. **Calculate the optical path \(L\) in the medium**:
   We have already calculated:
   \(L = 2 \int_0^d \frac{n(y)^2}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}} dy\)
   Substituting variables \(u = n(y) = n_a + ky\), \(dy = \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} du\).
   \(L = 2 \int_{n_a}^{n_b} \frac{u^2}{\sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i}} \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} du = \frac{2d}{n_b - n_a} \int_{n_a}^{n_b} \frac{u^2}{\sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i}} du\)
   Using the integration formula \(\int \frac{x^2 dx}{\sqrt{x^2 - A^2}} = \frac{x}{2} \sqrt{x^2 - A^2} + \frac{A^2}{2} \ln|x + \sqrt{x^2 - A^2}| + C\), where \(A = \sin i\).
   \(L = \frac{2d}{n_b - n_a} \left[ \frac{u}{2} \sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i} + \frac{\sin^2 i}{2} \ln(u + \sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i}) \right]_{n_a}^{n_b}\)
   \(L = \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} \left[ u \sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i} + \sin^2 i \ln(u + \sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i}) \right]_{n_a}^{n_b}\)
   \(L = \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} \left[ n_b\sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i} - n_a\sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i} + \sin^2 i \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) \right]\)

2. **Calculate the horizontal displacement \(2S\)**:
   We have already calculated:
   \(2S = 2 \int_0^d \frac{\sin i}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}} dy\)
   \(2S = 2 \sin i \int_0^d \frac{dy}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}\)
   \(2S = 2 \sin i \left[ \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} \int_{n_a}^{n_b} \frac{du}{\sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right]\)
   \(2S = \frac{2d \sin i}{n_b - n_a} \left[ \ln(u + \sqrt{u^2 - \sin^2 i}) \right]_{n_a}^{n_b}\)
   \(2S = \frac{2d \sin i}{n_b - n_a} \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right)\)

3. **Calculate the optical path difference \(L_0\) in air**:
   \(L_0 = 2S \sin i\)
   \(L_0 = \left[ \frac{2d \sin i}{n_b - n_a} \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) \right] \sin i\)
   \(L_0 = \frac{2d \sin^2 i}{n_b - n_a} \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right)\)

4. **Calculate the total optical path difference \(\Delta L\)**:
   \(\Delta L = L - L_0\)
   \(\Delta L = \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} \left[ n_b\sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i} - n_a\sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i} + \sin^2 i \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) \right] - \frac{2d \sin^2 i}{n_b - n_a} \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right)\)
   \(\Delta L = \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} \left[ n_b\sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i} - n_a\sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i} + (\sin^2 i - 2\sin^2 i) \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) \right]\)
   \(\Delta L = \frac{d}{n_b - n_a} \left[ n_b\sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i} - n_a\sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i} - \sin^2 i \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) \right]\)

5. **Calculate the phase difference \(\varphi\)**:
   \(\varphi = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda} \Delta L\)
   \[ \varphi = \frac{2\pi d}{\lambda (n_b - n_a)} \left[ n_b\sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i} - n_a\sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i} - \sin^2 i \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) \right] \]
   Or written in the form of arccosh:
   \[ \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) = \text{arccosh}\left(\frac{n_b}{\sin i}\right) - \text{arccosh}\left(\frac{n_a}{\sin i}\right) \]
   Therefore:
   \[ \varphi = \frac{2\pi d}{\lambda (n_b - n_a)} \left[ n_b\sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i} - n_a\sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i} - \sin^2 i \left( \text{arccosh}\left(\frac{n_b}{\sin i}\right) - \text{arccosh}\left(\frac{n_a}{\sin i}\right) \right) \right] \]

Final answer:
The phase difference \(\varphi\) between the two beams is:
\[ \varphi = \frac{2\pi d}{\lambda (n_b - n_a)} \left[ n_b\sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i} - n_a\sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i} - \sin^2 i \ln \left( \frac{n_b + \sqrt{n_b^2 - \sin^2 i}}{n_a + \sqrt{n_a^2 - \sin^2 i}} \right) \right] \]

The phase difference \(\varphi\) between the two adjacent beams of light is derived by considering the optical path and the initial phase differences at the point of interest, which is the exit point of the first beam and the incident point of the second beam at \((2S, 0)\).

The incident light is a plane wave with wavelength \(\lambda\) in air (refractive index \(n_0 = 1\)), incident at an angle \(i\). The phase of the incident wave at any point \((x, 0)\) on the lower surface is given by \(\phi_{\text{inc}}(x, 0) = k_0 \sin i \cdot x\), where \(k_0 = 2\pi / \lambda\).

For the first beam incident at \((0, 0)\), the phase at entry is \(\phi_{\text{inc}}(0, 0) = 0\) (taken as the phase reference). After traveling through the film, reflecting once at the upper surface, and exiting at \((2S, 0)\), the accumulated phase due to propagation is determined by the optical path length (OPL). The refractive index varies linearly with \(y\) as \(n(y) = n_a + \frac{n_b - n_a}{d} y\). The OPL for the path from \((0, 0)\) to \((2S, 0)\) via the reflection point is:
\[
\text{OPL}_{\text{total}} = 2 \int_{0}^{d} \frac{n(y)^2}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}  dy,
\]
leading to the exit phase:
\[
\phi_{\text{exit}_1} = k_0 \cdot \text{OPL}_{\text{total}} = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda} \cdot 2 \int_{0}^{d} \frac{n(y)^2}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}  dy = \frac{4\pi}{\lambda} \int_{0}^{d} \frac{n(y)^2}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}  dy.
\]

For the second beam incident at \((2S, 0)\), the incident phase is:
\[
\phi_{\text{inc}_2} = k_0 \sin i \cdot 2S.
\]
Given that \(S = \int_{0}^{d} \frac{\sin i}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}  dy\), this phase is:
\[
\phi_{\text{inc}_2} = \frac{4\pi}{\lambda} \sin^2 i \int_{0}^{d} \frac{1}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}  dy.
\]

The phase difference \(\varphi\) at \((2S, 0)\) is \(\phi_{\text{exit}_1} - \phi_{\text{inc}_2}\). Substituting the expressions:
\[
\varphi = \frac{4\pi}{\lambda} \left[ \int_{0}^{d} \frac{n(y)^2}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}  dy - \sin^2 i \int_{0}^{d} \frac{1}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}}  dy \right].
\]
Simplifying the integrand:
\[
\frac{n(y)^2}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}} - \frac{\sin^2 i}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}} = \frac{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}{\sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}} = \sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}.
\]
Thus:
\[
\varphi = \frac{4\pi}{\lambda} \int_{0}^{d} \sqrt{n(y)^2 - \sin^2 i}  dy,
\]
where \(n(y) = n_a + \frac{n_b - n_a}{d} y\).

This expression is independent of \(S\), as required.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\varphi = \frac{4\pi}{\lambda} \int_{0}^{d} \sqrt{ n^{2}(y) - \sin^{2} i  }  dy}
\]

questions: There is a centrally symmetric magnetic field in space that is directed inward perpendicular to the paper. The magnitude of the magnetic field varies with distance $r$ from the center O, and is given by the formula ${\mathbf{B}(\mathbf{r})=\mathbf{B}_{0}\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{n}}$. A charged particle with charge $q$ and mass $m$ moves in uniform circular motion of radius $R$ around O in the plane perpendicular to the magnetic field. If the particle is given a small radial disturbance, it will oscillate slightly along the radial direction. Find the period of these small oscillations.
solutions: (1) According to Newton's second law:  $$ {\mathfrak{q B}}_{0}v_{0}={\frac{m v_{0}^{2}}{R}} $$  We obtain:  $$ \mathrm{v}_{0}={\frac{q B_{0}R}{m}} $$  (2) The principle of angular momentum:  $$ \frac{d\mathrm{L}}{d t}=\mathrm{B}_{0}\Big(\frac{r}{R}\Big)^{n}r q\dot{r} $$  Rearrange terms:  $$ dL-\frac{B_0q}{R^n}r^{n+1}dr=0 $$  Integrate and substitute the result from question (1):  $$ \mathrm{L}-\frac{\mathrm{B}_{0}q}{(n+2)R^{n}}r^{n+2}=q B_{0}R^{2}(1-\frac{1}{n+2}) $$  (3) Conservation of energy:  $$ {\frac{{\mathbf{L}}^{2}}{2m r^{2}}}+{\frac{1}{2}}m{\dot{r}}^{2}=c $$  That is:  $$ \frac{(q B_{0}R^{2}\Big(1-\frac{1}{n+2}\Big)+\frac{{\bf B}_{0}q}{(n+2)R^{n}}r^{n+2})^{2}}{2m r^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}m{\dot{r}}^{2}=c $$  Differentiate the above equation with respect to time:  $$ \mathrm{m}\ddot{r}+\frac{(n+1)B_{0}^{2}q^{2}r^{2n+1}}{m(n+2)^{2}R^{2n}}+\frac{q^{2}B_{0}^{2}n(n+1)r^{n-1}}{(n+2)^{2}R^{n-2}m}-\frac{q^{2}B_{0}^{2}R^{4}(n+1)^{2}}{m(n+2)^{2}r^{3}}=0 $$  Let:  $$ {\bf{r}}={\bf{R}}+\delta{\bf{r}} $$  Expand the above equation for small quantities and get:  $$ \mathrm{m}\ddot{\delta{r}}+\frac{(n+1)B_{0}^{2}q^{2}(2n+1)\delta r}{m(n+2)^{2}}+\frac{q^{2}B_{0}^{2}n(n+1)(n-1)\delta r}{(n+2)^{2}m}+\frac{3 q^{2}B_{0}^{2}R^{4}(n+1)^{2}\delta r}{m(n+2)^{2}}=0 $$  That is:  $$ \mathrm{m}\ddot{\delta{r}}+(n+1)\frac{q^2B_{0}^2\delta r}{m}=0 $$  The above equation is the standard formula for simple harmonic motion, yielding:  $$ \displaystyle\mathbb{T}=\frac{2\pi}{\sqrt{n+1}}\frac{m}{q B_{0}} $$
improved_solutions:
The period of small radial oscillations for a charged particle in a centrally symmetric magnetic field is derived by analyzing the equations of motion and using the conserved canonical angular momentum due to the azimuthal symmetry of the magnetic field.

The magnetic field is given by \(\mathbf{B}(\mathbf{r}) = -B_0 \left( \frac{r}{R} \right)^n \hat{z}\), where the negative sign indicates the inward direction (perpendicular to the plane of motion). The particle has charge \(q\) and mass \(m\), and initially moves in uniform circular motion at radius \(R\) with angular speed \(\omega_0 = \frac{q B_0}{m}\).

The conserved canonical angular momentum is:
\[
p_\theta = m r^2 \dot{\theta} + q r A_\theta(r),
\]
where the vector potential \(A_\theta(r)\) is derived from the magnetic field:
\[
A_\theta(r) = -\frac{B_0 r^{n+1}}{(n+2) R^n}.
\]
Using the initial conditions at \(r = R\) and \(\dot{\theta} = \omega_0\), the constant \(p_\theta\) is:
\[
p_\theta = \frac{q B_0 R^2 (n+1)}{n+2}.
\]
Thus, for general \(r\),
\[
\dot{\theta} = \frac{q B_0}{(n+2) m r^2} \left( (n+1) R^2 + \frac{r^{n+2}}{R^n} \right).
\]

The radial equation of motion is:
\[
m (\ddot{r} - r \dot{\theta}^2) = F_r = q (r \dot{\theta}) B_z,
\]
where \(B_z = -B_0 (r/R)^n\). Substituting and simplifying:
\[
\ddot{r} = r \dot{\theta}^2 - \frac{q B_0}{m} r^{n+1} \dot{\theta} R^{-n}.
\]
Substituting \(\dot{\theta}\) and simplifying gives \(\ddot{r}\) as a function of \(r\). For small radial oscillations around \(r = R\), set \(r = R + \rho\) with \(\rho\) small. The equation becomes:
\[
\ddot{\rho} \approx -\left( \frac{q^2 B_0^2}{m^2} (n+1)^2 \right) \rho.
\]
This is the equation for simple harmonic motion with angular frequency:
\[
\omega_{\text{osc}} = \frac{q B_0}{m} (n+1).
\]
The period of oscillation is:
\[
T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega_{\text{osc}}} = \frac{2\pi m}{q B_0 (n+1)}.
\]

This result is consistent for the given magnetic field profile, and the period depends on the parameters \(m\), \(q\), \(B_0\), and the exponent \(n\).

### Final Answer
\[ \boxed{\dfrac{2\pi m}{q B_0 (n + 1)}} \]

questions: Establish a Cartesian coordinate system Oxyz, with a hypothetical sphere of radius $R$ at the origin. Place $n$ rings of radius $R$ along the meridional circles, all passing through the points (0, 0, R) and (0, 0, -R). The angle between any two adjacent rings is $\frac{\pi}{n}$, and each ring is uniformly charged with positive charge $Q$. The setup is stationary, and a negative charge $−q$ with mass $m$ is performing circular motion on the equatorial plane at a distance $r_{0}$ from the center of the sphere ($r_0\gg R$). Now, give the charge a radial disturbance, and attempt to find the difference between its radial oscillation period and angular revolution period.   The vacuum permittivity is known as $\epsilon_0$.
solutions: Consider the case of a single circular loop, establishing a spherical coordinate system $(r, \alpha)$ with the loop axis as the polar axis. Then:  $$ V = {\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}\int_{0}^{2\pi}{\frac{Q d\theta}{2\pi}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{r^{2}+R^{2}-2R r \sin\alpha \cos\Theta}}}={\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}\left({\frac{1}{r}}+{\frac{R^{2}}{r^{3}}}{\frac{1-3\cos^{2}\alpha}{2}}\right)\#\left({\frac{1}{r}}+{\frac{R^{2}}{r^{2}}}\right). $$  Next, consider the superposition of multiple circular loops. Based on geometric relations:  $$ V_{i}={\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}\left({\frac{1}{r}}+{\frac{R^{2}}{r^{3}}}{\frac{1-3\sin^{2}\theta\cos^{2}\left(\varphi-{\frac{\mathrm{i}\pi}{\mathrm{n}}}\right)}{2}}\right) $$  Summing results in:  $$ V={\frac{n Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}\left({\frac{1}{r}}-{\frac{R^{2}}{r^{3}}}{\frac{1-3\cos^{2}\theta}{4}}\right) $$  On the equatorial plane, $\textstyle{\theta={\frac{\pi}{2}}}$  $$ V={\frac{n Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}\left({\frac{1}{r}}-{\frac{R^{2}}{4r^{3}}}\right) $$  Assuming the angular momentum is $L=m\omega_{\theta}r_{0}^{2}$, the effective potential energy is  $$ \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{eff}}=-{\frac{n Q q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}\left({\frac{1}{r}}-{\frac{R^{2}}{4r^{3}}}\right)+{\frac{L^{2}}{2m r^{2}}} $$  The first derivative set to zero:  $$ -{\frac{n Q q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}{\left({\frac{-1}{r^{2}}}+{\frac{3R^{2}}{4r^{4}}}\right)}-{\frac{L^{2}}{m r^{3}}}=0 $$  Solving gives:  $$ \omega_{\theta}^{2}=\frac{n Q q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}m r_{0}}\left(\frac{1}{r_{0}^{2}}-\frac{3R^{2}}{4r_{0}^{4}}\right) $$  The second derivative:  $$ -{\frac{n Q q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}}}\left({\frac{2}{r^{3}}}-{\frac{3R^{2}}{r^{5}}}\right)+{\frac{3L^{2}}{m r^{4}}}=m\omega_{r}^{2} $$  Solving gives:  $$ \omega_{r}^{2}=\frac{n Q q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}m r_{0}}\left(\frac{1}{r_{0}^{2}}+\frac{3R^{2}}{4r_{0}^{4}}\right) $$  $$ T_{r}-T_{\oplus}=\frac{2\pi}{\omega^{2}}(\omega_{\theta}-\omega_{r})=-\frac{3\pi R^{2}}{2r_{0}^{2}}\sqrt{\frac{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}m r_{0}^{3}}{n Q q}} $$

The electric field on the equatorial plane, due to the symmetric arrangement of the rings, is radial. For \(r \gg R\), the radial electric field \(E_r(r)\) is approximated using a multipole expansion:

Solving for the tangential velocity \(v\):
\[
v^2 = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{nQ}{m r_0} \left( 1 - \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right).
\]
The angular revolution frequency \(\omega_{\text{rev}} = v / r_0\) is:
\[
\omega_{\text{rev}}^2 = \frac{v^2}{r_0^2} = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{nQ}{m r_0^3} \left( 1 - \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right).
\]
The revolution period is \(T_{\text{rev}} = 2\pi / \omega_{\text{rev}}\).

After a radial disturbance, the motion is analyzed using the radial equation of motion with conservation of angular momentum. The angular momentum \(L\) is conserved and evaluated at the circular orbit:
\[
L = m r_0 v = m r_0 \sqrt{ \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{nQ}{m r_0} \left( 1 - \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right) } = \sqrt{ m q r_0 \frac{nQ}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \left( 1 - \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right) }.
\]
The radial equation of motion is:
\[
m \ddot{r} = F_r(r) + \frac{L^2}{m r^3}.
\]
For small radial displacements \(r = r_0 + \delta r\) with \(|\delta r| \ll r_0\), linearizing around \(r_0\) gives:
\[
m \ddot{\delta r} = f'(r_0) \delta r,
\]
where \(f(r) = F_r(r) + L^2 / (m r^3)\). The derivative \(f'(r)\) evaluated at \(r_0\) is:
\[
f'(r_0) = -\frac{q n Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} r_0^{-3} \left( 1 + \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right).
\]
The radial oscillation frequency \(\omega_{\text{osc}}\) satisfies:
\[
\omega_{\text{osc}}^2 = -\frac{f'(r_0)}{m} = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{nQ}{m r_0^3} \left( 1 + \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right).
\]
The oscillation period is \(T_{\text{osc}} = 2\pi / \omega_{\text{osc}}\).

Defining \(\omega_0^2 = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{nQ}{m r_0^3}\), the frequencies are:
\[
\omega_{\text{rev}}^2 \approx \omega_0^2 \left( 1 - \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right), \quad \omega_{\text{osc}}^2 \approx \omega_0^2 \left( 1 + \frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right).
\]
For small \(R/r_0\), the frequencies are approximated as:
\[
\omega_{\text{rev}} \approx \omega_0 \left( 1 - \frac{3R^2}{16r_0^2} \right), \quad \omega_{\text{osc}} \approx \omega_0 \left( 1 + \frac{3R^2}{16r_0^2} \right).
\]
The periods are:
\[
T_{\text{rev}} \approx \frac{2\pi}{\omega_0} \left( 1 + \frac{3R^2}{16r_0^2} \right), \quad T_{\text{osc}} \approx \frac{2\pi}{\omega_0} \left( 1 - \frac{3R^2}{16r_0^2} \right).
\]
The difference \(T_{\text{osc}} - T_{\text{rev}}\) is:
\[
T_{\text{osc}} - T_{\text{rev}} \approx \frac{2\pi}{\omega_0} \left[ \left(1 - \frac{3R^2}{16r_0^2}\right) - \left(1 + \frac{3R^2}{16r_0^2}\right) \right] = \frac{2\pi}{\omega_0} \left( -\frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \right).
\]
Substituting \(\omega_0 = \sqrt{ \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \frac{nQ}{m r_0^3} }\) and \(\frac{2\pi}{\omega_0} = 2\pi \sqrt{ \frac{4\pi\epsilon_0 m r_0^3}{q n Q} }\):
\[
T_{\text{osc}} - T_{\text{rev}} \approx -\frac{3R^2}{8r_0^2} \cdot 2\pi \sqrt{ \frac{4\pi\epsilon_0 m r_0^3}{q n Q} } = -\frac{3\pi R^2}{4r_0^2} \sqrt{ \frac{4\pi\epsilon_0 m r_0^3}{q n Q} }.
\]
Simplifying the expression:
\[
\frac{R^2}{r_0^2} \sqrt{r_0^3} = R^2 r_0^{-1/2},
\]
so:
\[
T_{\text{osc}} - T_{\text{rev}} \approx -\frac{3\pi R^2}{4} \sqrt{ \frac{4\pi\epsilon_0 m}{q n Q r_0} }.
\]
This is the difference between the radial oscillation period and the angular revolution period, valid to leading order in \(R/r_0\).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{T_{\text{osc}} - T_{\text{rev}} = -\dfrac{3\pi R^{2}}{4} \sqrt{\dfrac{4\pi \epsilon_{0} m}{q n Q r_{0}}}}
\]

questions: B and C are two smooth fixed pulleys with negligible size, positioned on the same horizontal line. A and D are two objects both with mass $m$, connected by a light and thin rope that passes over the fixed pulleys. Initially, the system is stationary, and the distances between AB and CD are both in the direction of gravity, where the distance between AB is $x_{0}$ and the distance between CD is $L$, which is sufficiently large such that D will not touch C within the time frame discussed in the problem. At this moment, ball A is pulled so that the line AB deviates from the vertical line by a small angle $\theta_{0}$ (without changing the length of AB), and the system begins to move. Taking gravitational acceleration as $\pmb{g}$, and assuming that A descends very slowly so that we can approximately consider the length of AB remains unchanged, A moves around B with a pendulum-like motion. Try to solve for the amplitude of the oscillation angle $\theta$ of A when $AB=x$.
solutions: Let the tension in the rope be $\intercal$. According to Newton's second law for block D, $T-mg=m{\ddot{x}}$ (1). Using the given assumptions, write the relation of the pendulum's oscillation angle with time:  $$ \theta_{t} = \theta \cos(\sqrt{\frac{g}{x}}t + \phi) $$    For $\mathsf{A}$, write down the expression of Newton's second law:  $$ mg-T+m\dot{\theta}_{t}^{2}x = m\ddot{x} $$    Combining (2) and (3), we get:  $$ mg-T+{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}}mg\theta^{2}=m\ddot{x} $$    Since the work done on A by the tension in the rope and the gravity of A is equal to the increment in A's kinetic energy, and A's kinetic energy can be separately written as the kinetic energy of vertical motion and the kinetic energy of oscillation (as the oscillation angle is small, the two can be considered independent):  $$ (mg-T)\dot{x}=\frac{d}{dt}(\frac{1}{2}m\dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}mg x\theta^{2}) $$    Combining (1), (4), and (5), we get:  $$ g\theta^{2}=4\ddot{x} \quad -\ddot{x}\dot{x}=\frac{d}{dt}(\frac{1}{2}\dot{x}^{2}+2x\ddot{x}) $$    $\textstyle{\bar{\mathcal{F}}}\psi/{\bar{\mathcal{H}}}{\ddot{x}}dx={\frac{1}{2}}d{\dot{x}}^{2}$, simplifying the above equation, we get:  $$ \dot{x}^{2}+2x\ddot{x}=const $$    Using the initial conditions at $\mathtt{t}{=}0$:  $$ x=x_{0} \quad \ddot{x}=g\theta_{0}^{2}/4 $$    We can rewrite equation (8) as:  $$ \dot{x}^{2}+2x\ddot{x}=g\theta_{0}^{2}x_{0}/2 $$    Multiplying both sides of the above equation by ${\mathsf{dx}}$, and using $\ddot{\bf x}dx=\frac{1}{2}d\dot{x}^{2}$, we get:  $$ \dot{x}^{2}dx+xd\dot{x}^{2}=d(x\dot{x}^{2})=\frac{1}{2}g\theta_{0}^{2}x_{0}dx $$    Integrating, we obtain:  $$ \dot{x}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}g\theta_{0}^{2}x_{0}(x-x_{0})/x $$    Differentiating both sides with respect to time, eliminating the first-order derivative of $\mathsf{x}$ with respect to $\mathtt{t}$, we get:  $$ \ddot{x}=\frac{1}{4}g\theta_{0}^{2}\frac{x_{0}^{2}}{x^{2}} $$    Combining with equation (6), we can solve for the amplitude of the oscillation angle $\theta$:  $$ \theta=\theta_{0}\frac{x_{0}}{x} $$
improved_solutions:
The system consists of two masses \(m\) connected by a light, inextensible rope passing over fixed pulleys B and C on the same horizontal line. Initially, the distance AB is \(x_0\) and CD is \(L\), with the system stationary. Mass A is displaced such that AB makes a small angle \(\theta_0\) with the vertical, without changing its length, and released. The descent of A is slow, allowing the length AB to be treated as approximately constant during the oscillation, and A undergoes pendulum-like motion about B.

For a pendulum with slowly varying length, the adiabatic invariant is conserved. For small oscillations, the energy \(E\) and angular frequency \(\omega\) of the pendulum are related by \(E / \omega = \text{constant}\), where \(E \propto r \theta_{\text{max}}^2\) and \(\omega \propto r^{-1/2}\) with \(r = AB\).

The energy for a pendulum of length \(r\) and angular amplitude \(\theta_{\text{max}}\) is approximately:
\[
E = \frac{1}{2} m g r \theta_{\text{max}}^2
\]
The angular frequency is:
\[
\omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{r}}
\]
Thus,
\[
\frac{E}{\omega} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} m g r \theta_{\text{max}}^2}{\sqrt{\frac{g}{r}}} = \frac{1}{2} m g r \theta_{\text{max}}^2 \sqrt{\frac{r}{g}} = \frac{1}{2} m \theta_{\text{max}}^2 \sqrt{g}  r^{3/2}
\]
Since \(E / \omega\) is constant,
\[
\theta_{\text{max}}^2 r^{3/2} = \text{constant}
\]
Initially, \(r = x_0\) and \(\theta_{\text{max}} = \theta_0\), so:
\[
\theta_0^2 x_0^{3/2} = \text{constant}
\]
At any later time when \(AB = x\), the amplitude \(\theta\) satisfies:
\[
\theta^2 x^{3/2} = \theta_0^2 x_0^{3/2}
\]
Solving for \(\theta\):
\[
\theta^2 = \theta_0^2 \left( \frac{x_0}{x} \right)^{3/2} \cdot \frac{1}{x^{3/2} - 3/2 + 3/2} \quad \text{(incorrect step, see below)}
\]
From \(\theta^2 x^{3/2} = \theta_0^2 x_0^{3/2}\):
\[
\theta^2 = \theta_0^2 \left( \frac{x_0}{x} \right)^{3/2} \cdot \frac{1}{x^{0}} \quad \text{(misstep)}
\]
Correctly:
\[
\theta^2 = \theta_0^2 \frac{x_0^{3/2}}{x^{3/2}} = \theta_0^2 \left( \frac{x_0}{x} \right)^{3/2}
\]
Thus,
\[
\theta = \theta_0 \left( \frac{x_0}{x} \right)^{3/4}
\]
The amplitude of the oscillation angle \(\theta\) is therefore \(\theta_0 (x_0 / x)^{3/4}\).

The slow descent and connection to mass D do not affect this result under the adiabatic approximation, as the oscillation is rapid compared to the descent, and the adiabatic invariant remains conserved.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\theta_0 \left( \dfrac{x_0}{x} \right)^{\dfrac{3}{4}}}
\]

questions:
AB is a uniform thin rod with mass $m$ and length $l_{2}$. The upper end B of the rod is suspended from a fixed point O by an inextensible soft and light string, which has a length of $l_{1}$. Initially, both the string and the rod are hanging vertically and at rest. Subsequently, all motion occurs in the same vertical plane, with all angles rotating counterclockwise being positive.

Assume at a certain moment, the angles between the string, the rod, and the vertical direction are $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ respectively. The angular velocities of the string around the fixed point O and the rod around its center of mass are $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ respectively. Determine the angular acceleration $\alpha_{2}$ of the rod around its center of mass, expressing the answer only in terms of the physical quantities given in the problem and the gravitational acceleration $g$.
solutions:
In the vertical plane where points O, B, and A are located, establish a plane coordinate system with point O as the origin, the horizontal ray to the right as the $\mathbf{X}$ axis, and the vertical ray upward as the $\mathbf{y}$ axis. The acceleration of the pole's center of mass C, denoted as $(\boldsymbol{a}_{\mathrm{G}x},\boldsymbol{a}_{\mathrm{G}y})$, satisfies the center of mass motion theorem

$$
m a_{\mathrm{c}x}=-T\sin\theta_{1},m a_{\mathrm{c}y}=-m g+T\cos\theta_{1}\textcircled{7}
$$ 

In this equation, $T$ is the magnitude of the tension in the rope. At the same time, the pole rotates around its center of mass under the moment caused by the rope tension $T$ relative to the center of mass. By the rotational theorem, we have

$$
\frac{1}{12}m l_{2}^{2}\alpha_{2}=-T\frac{1}{2}l_{2}\sin(\theta_{2}-\theta_{1})\textcircled{8}
$$ 

From the geometric relationship, we have

$$
x_{\mathrm{{B}}}(t)=x_{\mathrm{{C}}}(t)-{\frac{1}{2}}l_{2}\sin\theta_{2}(t),y_{\mathrm{{B}}}(t)=y_{\mathrm{{C}}}(t)+{\frac{1}{2}}l_{2}\cos\theta_{2}(t)
$$ 

Differentiating both sides of the above equations with respect to time $t$, the velocity of point B satisfies the conditions

$$
{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\mathrm{{B}}x}(t)={\boldsymbol{v}}_{\mathrm{{C}}x}(t)-{\frac{1}{2}}{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{2}(t){\boldsymbol{l}}_{2}\cos\theta_{2}(t),\quad{\boldsymbol{v}}_{\mathrm{{B}}y}(t)={\boldsymbol{v}}_{\mathrm{{C}}y}(t)-{\frac{1}{2}}{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{2}(t){\boldsymbol{l}}_{2}\sin\theta_{2}(t),
$$ 

Differentiating both sides of the above equations with respect to time $t$ again, the acceleration of point B satisfies the conditions

$$
a_{\mathrm{B}x}=a_{\mathrm{C}x}-\frac{1}{2}\alpha_{2}l_{2}\cos\theta_{2}+\frac{1}{2}\omega_{2}^{2}l_{2}\sin\theta_{2},a_{\mathrm{B}y}=a_{\mathrm{C}y}-\frac{1}{2}\alpha_{2}l_{2}\sin\theta_{2}-\frac{1}{2}\omega_{2}^{2}l_{2}\cos\theta_{2}
$$ 

Meanwhile, point B rotates around point O with a fixed axis under the condition of an inextensible rope, thus

$$
x_{\mathrm{{B}}}(t)=l_{\mathrm{{1}}}\sin\theta_{\mathrm{{1}}}(t),y_{\mathrm{{B}}}(t)=-l_{\mathrm{{1}}}\cos\theta_{\mathrm{{1}}}(t)
$$ 

Differentiating both sides of the above equations with respect to time $t$, the velocity of point B also satisfies the conditions

$$
V_{_{\mathrm{B}x}}(t)=\omega_{1}(t)l_{1}\cos\theta_{1}(t),~V_{_{\mathrm{B}y}}(t)=\omega_{1}(t)l_{1}\sin\theta_{1}(t)
$$ 

Differentiating both sides of the above equations with respect to time $t$ again, the acceleration of point B also satisfies the conditions

$$
a_{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathrm{B}x}}=\alpha_{1}l_{1}\cos\theta_{1}-\alpha_{1}^{2}l_{1}\sin\theta_{1},a_{{\scriptscriptstyle{\mathrm{B}y}}}=\alpha_{1}l_{1}\sin\theta_{1}+\omega_{1}^{2}l_{1}\cos\theta_{1}
$$ 

The angular accelerations of the rope around the suspension point and the pole around the center of mass can be solved as

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\alpha_{2}=\cfrac{3\sin(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})\left[2g\cos\theta_{1}+2l_{1}\omega_{1}^{2}+l_{2}\omega_{2}^{2}\cos(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})\right]}{l_{2}\left[1+3\sin^{2}(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2})\right]}}\end{array}
$$
improved_solutions:
The angular acceleration \(\alpha_2\) of the rod around its center of mass is derived using Lagrangian mechanics. The system has two degrees of freedom, characterized by the angles \(\theta_1\) and \(\theta_2\), with corresponding angular velocities \(\omega_1 = \dot{\theta}_1\) and \(\omega_2 = \dot{\theta}_2\). The Lagrangian \(L = T - V\) is formulated, where \(T\) is the kinetic energy and \(V\) is the potential energy.

The position of the center of mass \(G\) of the rod is given by:
\[
x_G = l_1 \sin \theta_1 + \frac{l_2}{2} \sin \theta_2, \quad y_G = -l_1 \cos \theta_1 - \frac{l_2}{2} \cos \theta_2.
\]
The velocities are:
\[
v_{Gx} = l_1 \cos \theta_1  \dot{\theta}_1 + \frac{l_2}{2} \cos \theta_2  \dot{\theta}_2, \quad v_{Gy} = l_1 \sin \theta_1  \dot{\theta}_1 + \frac{l_2}{2} \sin \theta_2  \dot{\theta}_2.
\]
The kinetic energy \(T\) is the sum of translational and rotational components:
\[
T = \frac{1}{2} m (v_{Gx}^2 + v_{Gy}^2) + \frac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}_2^2,
\]
where the moment of inertia about the center of mass is \(I = \frac{1}{12} m l_2^2\). Substituting and simplifying:
\[
v_{Gx}^2 + v_{Gy}^2 = l_1^2 \dot{\theta}_1^2 + \left( \frac{l_2}{2} \dot{\theta}_2 \right)^2 + l_1 l_2 \dot{\theta}_1 \dot{\theta}_2 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2),
\]
\[
T = \frac{1}{2} m l_1^2 \dot{\theta}_1^2 + \frac{1}{2} m l_1 l_2 \dot{\theta}_1 \dot{\theta}_2 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + \frac{1}{6} m l_2^2 \dot{\theta}_2^2.
\]
The potential energy \(V\) is:
\[
V = m g y_G = m g \left( -l_1 \cos \theta_1 - \frac{l_2}{2} \cos \theta_2 \right).
\]
The Lagrangian is:
\[
L = \frac{1}{2} m l_1^2 \dot{\theta}_1^2 + \frac{1}{2} m l_1 l_2 \dot{\theta}_1 \dot{\theta}_2 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + \frac{1}{6} m l_2^2 \dot{\theta}_2^2 - m g \left( -l_1 \cos \theta_1 - \frac{l_2}{2} \cos \theta_2 \right).
\]
Applying Lagrange's equations for \(\theta_2\):
\[
\frac{d}{dt} \left( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}_2} \right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta_2} = 0.
\]
The partial derivatives are:
\[
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}_2} = \frac{1}{2} m l_1 l_2 \dot{\theta}_1 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + \frac{1}{3} m l_2^2 \dot{\theta}_2,
\]
\[
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta_2} = \frac{1}{2} m l_1 l_2 \dot{\theta}_1 \dot{\theta}_2 \sin(\theta_1 - \theta_2) - m g \frac{l_2}{2} \sin \theta_2.
\]
After differentiation and simplification, the equation for \(\theta_2\) is:
\[
l_1 \ddot{\theta}_1 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2) - l_1 \dot{\theta}_1^2 \sin(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + \frac{2}{3} l_2 \ddot{\theta}_2 + g \sin \theta_2 = 0.
\]
Similarly, for \(\theta_1\):
\[
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}_1} = m l_1^2 \dot{\theta}_1 + \frac{1}{2} m l_1 l_2 \dot{\theta}_2 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2),
\]
\[
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta_1} = -\frac{1}{2} m l_1 l_2 \dot{\theta}_1 \dot{\theta}_2 \sin(\theta_1 - \theta_2) - m g l_1 \sin \theta_1.
\]
After differentiation and simplification:
\[
l_1 \ddot{\theta}_1 + \frac{1}{2} l_2 \ddot{\theta}_2 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + \frac{1}{2} l_2 \dot{\theta}_2^2 \sin(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + g \sin \theta_1 = 0.
\]
Solving the system of equations for \(\ddot{\theta}_2 = \alpha_2\), with \(\dot{\theta}_1 = \omega_1\) and \(\dot{\theta}_2 = \omega_2\):
\[
\alpha_2 = \frac{ 6 \sin(\theta_1 - \theta_2) \left[ l_1 \omega_1^2 + \frac{1}{2} l_2 \omega_2^2 \cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + g \cos \theta_1 \right] }{ l_2 \left( 4 - 3 \cos^2 (\theta_1 - \theta_2) \right) }.
\]
The mass \(m\) cancels out, and the expression depends only on the given quantities \(l_1\), \(l_2\), \(\theta_1\), \(\theta_2\), \(\omega_1\), \(\omega_2\), and \(g\).

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\alpha_{2} = \dfrac{6\sin\left(\theta_{1} - \theta_{2}\right)\left(l_{1}\omega_{1}^{2} + \dfrac{1}{2}l_{2}\omega_{2}^{2}\cos\left(\theta_{1} - \theta_{2}\right) + g\cos\theta_{1}\right)}{l_{2}\left(4 - 3\cos^{2}\left(\theta_{1} - \theta_{2}\right)\right)}}
\]

questions: Xiao Ming discovered an elliptical plate at home with semi-major and semi-minor axes of \( A \) and \( B \), respectively. Using one focus \( F \) as the origin, a polar coordinate system was established such that the line connecting the focus and the vertex closest to the focus defines the polar axis direction. Through extremely precise measurements, it was found that the mass surface density satisfies the equation \(\sigma = \sigma_{0}(1 + e\cos\varphi)^3\), where \( e \) is the eccentricity of the ellipse. When the plate's major axis is positioned vertically and released from rest on a sufficiently rough tabletop, the plate moves only within the plane it lies in. Find the angular acceleration \(\beta\) of the plate when the major axis becomes horizontal.
solutions:
At this time, the angular velocity is $\omega$, the angular acceleration is $\beta$, and the acceleration of the center of mass is $a_{x}, a_{y}$.

The moment of inertia about the instantaneous center $\mathrm{P}$ is $I_{P}=I+m A^{2}$.

From the conservation of energy, the contact condition at point P gives the acceleration  
$a = \omega^2 \rho = \omega^2 \frac{A^2}{B}$.

Considering the rotational theorem about the instantaneous center:  
$I_{P} \vec{\beta} = \vec{M} - m \vec{r}_{c} \times \vec{a}$

We obtain:  

$$
I_{P} \beta = m \sqrt{A^2 - B^2} \bigg(g + \omega^{2} \frac{A^{2}}{B} \bigg)
$$

$$
\beta = 4A \sqrt{A^2 - B^2} g \frac{2A^{4} + 2A^{3} \sqrt{A^2 - B^2} - A^{3}B + B^{4}}{(2A^{3} + B^{3})^{2}B}
$$
improved_solutions:
The elliptical plate has semi-major axis \(A\) and semi-minor axis \(B\), with eccentricity \(e = \sqrt{1 - (B/A)^2}\). The center of mass is located at the focus \(F\), which serves as the origin of the polar coordinate system. When the major axis is horizontal, the plate is pivoted about the point of contact \(P\) with the tabletop.

The position of \(P\) in the coordinate system with \(F\) at \((0,0)\) is \((-A e, -B)\). The vector from \(P\) to \(F\) (the center of mass) is \((A e, B)\). The gravitational force acts downward at \(F\), given by \(\vec{F}_g = (0, -M g)\), where \(M\) is the mass of the plate and \(g\) is the acceleration due to gravity.

The torque about \(P\) is:
\[
\tau_z = d_x F_y - d_y F_x = (A e)(-M g) - (B)(0) = -M g A e.
\]
The magnitude of the torque is \(|\tau_z| = M g A e\).

The moment of inertia about the center of mass \(F\) is:
\[
I_{\text{cm}} = \frac{1}{2} M A^2 (1 - e^2)^{3/2}.
\]
The distance from \(F\) to \(P\) is:
\[
d = \sqrt{(A e)^2 + B^2} = \sqrt{A^2 e^2 + A^2 (1 - e^2)} = \sqrt{A^2} = A,
\]
since \(A > 0\). Using the parallel axis theorem, the moment of inertia about \(P\) is:
\[
I_P = I_{\text{cm}} + M d^2 = \frac{1}{2} M A^2 (1 - e^2)^{3/2} + M A^2 = M A^2 \left[ 1 + \frac{1}{2} (1 - e^2)^{3/2} \right].
\]

The angular acceleration \(\beta\) about \(P\) is the magnitude of the angular acceleration, given by:
\[
\beta = \frac{|\tau_z|}{I_P} = \frac{M g A e}{M A^2 \left[ 1 + \frac{1}{2} (1 - e^2)^{3/2} \right]} = \frac{g e}{A \left[ 1 + \frac{1}{2} (1 - e^2)^{3/2} \right]}.
\]
Substituting \(e = \sqrt{1 - (B/A)^2}\) and \((1 - e^2)^{3/2} = (B/A)^3\), the expression simplifies to:
\[
\beta = \frac{2 g A \sqrt{A^2 - B^2}}{2 A^3 + B^3}.
\]

This is the angular acceleration at the instant when the major axis is horizontal.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\beta = \dfrac{2gA\sqrt{A^{2} - B^{2}}}{2A^{3} + B^{3}}}
\]

questions: \"Choose a sodium lamp for Young's double-slit interference experiment. The wavelengths of the sodium lamp's double yellow lines are $\lambda_{1}$ and $\lambda_{2}$ respectively. Due to a very small wavelength difference, the higher-order interference fringes on the screen will become blurred. Neglecting the width of the slits themselves, introduce the contrast function $\gamma \equiv\frac{I_{max}-I_{min}}{I_{max}+I_{min}}$ to measure the clarity of the interference. When $\gamma = 0$, the fringes will become blurred. Additionally, if the background light intensity becomes $1/e$ of the system's maximum possible light intensity, it will also cause the observer to subjectively perceive the interference fringes as too dim, leading to blurriness.  If the width of the double slits is $d$ and the horizontal distance from the screen to the double slits is $L$. Use a filter to filter out the light with a wavelength of $\lambda_{1}$. Due to the broadening of the spectral line caused by the thermal motion of molecules in the sodium lamp, if the temperature of the sodium lamp is $T$ and the mass of the sodium atom is $m$, try to calculate the position where the fringes become blurred for the first time. Assume that the sodium atoms follow the Maxwell velocity distribution law (and that the problem can be solved using the far-field condition).

### Solution to the Problem

The problem involves finding the position where the interference fringes first become blurred in a Young's double-slit interferometer using a sodium lamp, after filtering out one of the sodium doublet lines (wavelength \(\lambda_1\)) and accounting for thermal broadening of the remaining line (\(\lambda_2\)) due to the thermal motion of sodium atoms. The blurring is primarily due to the wavelength spread from thermal Doppler broadening, which reduces the fringe contrast. The contrast function \(\gamma = \frac{I_{\text{max}} - I_{\text{min}}}{I_{\text{max}} + I_{\text{min}}}\) is used, and \(\gamma = 0\) indicates blurred fringes. However, for thermal broadening, \(\gamma\) decreases continuously but never reaches zero. The "first time" the fringes become blurred is interpreted as the smallest position \(y\) where the fringes are significantly washed out, corresponding to when the standard deviation of the fringe position due to thermal broadening equals the fringe spacing.

#### Step 1: Thermal Broadening Analysis
The sodium atoms follow a Maxwell velocity distribution, leading to Doppler broadening of the spectral line at wavelength \(\lambda_2\). The central wavelength after filtering is \(\lambda_0 = \lambda_2\). The Doppler shift gives a wavelength spread:
\[
\Delta \lambda = \lambda - \lambda_0 = \lambda_0 \frac{v_z}{c},
\]
where \(v_z\) is the velocity component along the line of sight, and \(c\) is the speed of light. The distribution of \(v_z\) is Gaussian:
\[
p(v_z)  dv_z = \sqrt{\frac{m}{2\pi k_B T}} \exp\left(-\frac{m v_z^2}{2 k_B T}\right) dv_z,
\]
where \(m\) is the mass of a sodium atom, \(k_B\) is Boltzmann's constant, and \(T\) is the temperature. The distribution of \(\Delta \lambda\) is also Gaussian:
\[
p(\Delta \lambda)  d(\Delta \lambda) = \frac{1}{\sigma_\lambda \sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left(-\frac{(\Delta \lambda)^2}{2 \sigma_\lambda^2}\right) d(\Delta \lambda),
\]
with standard deviation:
\[
\sigma_\lambda = \lambda_0 \sqrt{\frac{k_B T}{m c^2}}.
\]

#### Step 2: Interference Pattern with Broadening
The intensity at position \(y\) on the screen for monochromatic light of wavelength \(\lambda\) is:
\[
I(y, \lambda) = \frac{I_0}{2} \left[ 1 + \cos \left( \frac{2\pi d y}{\lambda L} \right) \right],
\]
where \(d\) is the slit separation, \(L\) is the distance to the screen, and \(I_0\) is the maximum intensity at \(y = 0\) for no broadening. Due to the wavelength distribution, the average intensity is:
\[
\langle I(y) \rangle = \frac{I_0}{2} \left[ 1 + \left\langle \cos \left( \frac{2\pi d y}{\lambda L} \right) \right\rangle \right].
\]
With \(\lambda = \lambda_0 + \Delta \lambda\) and small broadening, the phase \(\phi = \frac{2\pi d y}{\lambda L}\) has fluctuations. After averaging, the contrast function \(\gamma(y)\) is:
\[
\gamma(y) = \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{2\pi d y}{\lambda_0 L} \right)^2 \frac{k_B T}{m c^2} \right).
\]
This \(\gamma(y)\) decreases as \(|y|\) increases but never reaches zero.

#### Step 3: Blurring Criterion
The fringes become blurred when \(\gamma = 0\), which is not achievable for thermal broadening. Instead, the blurring is defined to occur when the thermal broadening causes the fringe to be washed out, specifically when the standard deviation of the fringe position equals the fringe spacing. For the \(n\)-th bright fringe at \(y_n = n \lambda_0 L / d\), the fringe spacing is:
\[
\Delta y = \frac{\lambda_0 L}{d}.
\]
The standard deviation of \(y_n\) due to thermal broadening is derived from the variation in \(\lambda\):
\[
y_n = n \frac{\lambda L}{d}, \quad \sigma_y = \left| \frac{\partial y_n}{\partial \lambda} \right| \sigma_\lambda = n \frac{L}{d} \sigma_\lambda = n \frac{L}{d} \lambda_0 \sqrt{\frac{k_B T}{m c^2}}.
\]
Setting \(\sigma_y = \Delta y\):
\[
n \frac{L}{d} \lambda_0 \sqrt{\frac{k_B T}{m c^2}} = \frac{\lambda_0 L}{d},
\]
thus:
\[
n \sqrt{\frac{k_B T}{m c^2}} = 1, \quad n = \sqrt{\frac{m c^2}{k_B T}}.
\]
The position \(y\) corresponding to this fringe order is:
\[
y = n \frac{\lambda_0 L}{d} = \frac{\lambda_0 L}{d} \sqrt{\frac{m c^2}{k_B T}}.
\]

#### Step 4: Verification of Blurring
At this \(n\), the contrast \(\gamma(n)\) is:
\[
\gamma(n) = \exp\left( -2\pi^2 n^2 \frac{k_B T}{m c^2} \right) = \exp\left( -2\pi^2 \cdot \frac{m c^2}{k_B T} \cdot \frac{k_B T}{m c^2} \right) = \exp(-2\pi^2) \approx 2.5 \times 10^{-9},
\]
which is extremely small, effectively zero for practical purposes. Thus, the fringes are blurred at this position. Since \(\gamma(n)\) decreases rapidly with \(n\), and this is the smallest \(n\) where significant blurring occurs, it corresponds to the first time the fringes become blurred.

### Final Answer
The position on the screen where the interference fringes first become blurred is given by:
\[
\boxed{y = \dfrac{\lambda_{2} L}{d} \sqrt{\dfrac{m c^{2}}{k_{B} T}}}
\]
where \(\lambda_2\) is the wavelength of the unfiltered sodium line, \(L\) is the distance from the double slits to the screen, \(d\) is the slit separation, \(m\) is the mass of a sodium atom, \(c\) is the speed of light, \(k_B\) is Boltzmann's constant, and \(T\) is the temperature of the sodium lamp.

questions: In modern plasma physics experiments, negative particles are often constrained in two ways. In the following discussion, we do not consider relativistic effects or retarded potentials. To keep the point charge stable in both the $\hat{z}$ and $\hat{r}$ directions, we consider rotating the two charged rings in the $\hat{z}$ direction with a constant angular velocity $\Omega$. Given a small disturbance to the point charge at the origin, provide the minimum $\Omega$ required for the particle to remain stable in all directions.

A particle with mass $m$ and charge $q$ moves in a circular motion with radius $r_{0}$ around the center of symmetry under the influence of the magnetic field. Find: if the charged particle is given a small radial disturbance, determine the period $T$ of the small radial oscillations.

yields:  $$ d L - \frac{q B_{0}}{r_{0}^{n}} r^{n+1} d r = 0 \to L - \frac{q B_{0}}{(n+2) r_{0}^{n}} r^{n+2} = C = \frac{n+1}{n+2} q B_{0} r_{0}^{2} $$  (Conservation quantity 6 points)  Thus, we obtain the function of angular momentum and $r$:  $$ L = L(r) = \frac{q B_{0}}{n+2} \biggl(\frac{r^{n+2}}{r_{0}^{n}} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\biggr) $$  The energy conservation of the charged particle gives: r)^{n+2}}{r_{0}^{n}} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2}}{(r_{0}+\delta r)^{2}} = E $$  To analyze the oscillation, we need to expand the potential energy and retain terms up to the second order, so we first look at the denominator:  $$ \begin{array}{r l} &\left(\frac{(r_{0}+\delta r)^{n+2}}{r_{0}^{n}} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2} = \left(r_{0}^{2}\Bigl(1+\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Bigr)^{n+2} + (n+1) r_{0}^{2}\right)^{2} \\ &\qquad = r_{0}^{4} \Biggl(1 + (n+2) \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + \frac{(n+2)(n+1)}{2} \Bigl(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Bigr)^{2} + (n+1) \Biggr)^{2} \\ &\qquad = r_{0}^{4} (n+2)^{2} \Biggl(1 + \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + \frac{n+1}{2} \Bigl(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Bigr)^{2} \Biggr)^{2} = r_{0}^{4} (n+2)^{2} \left(1 + 2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + (n+2) \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{2} \end{array} $$  In the above equation, we repeatedly used the small quantity approximation formula $\begin{array}{r} (1+x)^{n} = 1 + n x + \frac{n(n-1)}{2}x^{2} + \ldots, \end{array}$ so the potential r}{r_{0}} + (n+2) \Big(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Big)^{2}\right) \left(1 + \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\right)^{-2} $$  $$ = r_{0}^{2} (n+2)^{2} \left(1 + 2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + (n+2) \Big(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Big)^{2}\right) \left(1 - 2 \frac{\delta r}{r_{0}} + 3 \Big(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\Big)^{2}\right) $$  Thus the second-order terms of potential energy are:  $$ \frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2m(n+2)^{2}} r_{0}^{2} (n+2)^{2} (n+1) \bigg(\frac{\delta r}{r_{0}}\bigg)^{2} = \frac{q^{2} B_{0}^{2}}{2m} (n+1) \delta r^{2} $$  (Correctly expanding small terms 12 points)  Thus, the The particle moves in a circular orbit of radius \(r_0\) under the influence of the magnetic field \(B(r) = B_0 \left( \frac{r}{r_0} \right)^n\). The initial speed \(v_0\) at radius \(r_0\) is determined by the balance between the magnetic force and the centripetal force:

\[
|q| v_0 B_0 = \frac{m v_0^2}{r_0}
\]

Solving for \(v_0\):

\[
v_0 = \frac{|q| B_0 r_0}{m}
\]

The angular frequency of the initial circular motion (cyclotron frequency) is:

\[
\omega_c = \frac{v_0}{r_0} = \frac{|q| B_0}{m}
\]

For small radial oscillations around \(r = r_0\), the radial equation of motion is derived using cylindrical coordinates. The radial acceleration is given by:

\[
m (\ddot{r} - r \dot{\phi}^2) = F_r
\]

where \(F_r = q B v_\phi\) is the radial component of the Lorentz force, and \(v_\phi = r \dot{\phi}\). The speed is constant due to the magnetic force doing no work:

\[
v^2 = \dot{r}^2 + (r \dot{\phi})^2 = v_0^2
\]

For small perturbations, \(\dot{r}\) is small, so \(v_\phi \approx v_0\) to first order. Substituting into the radial equation:

\[
m \ddot{r} - m \frac{v_0^2}{r} = q B v_0
\]

Define the right-hand side as a function of \(r\):

\[
f(r) = m \frac{v_0^2}{r} + q B(r) v_0
\]

At equilibrium (\(r = r_0\)), \(f(r_0) = 0\). Expanding \(f(r)\) around \(r_0\) with \(r = r_0 + \delta r\) and \(\delta r\) small:

\[
f(r) \approx f'(r_0) \delta r
\]

The derivative is:

\[
f'(r) = -\frac{m v_0^2}{r^2} + q v_0 \frac{dB}{dr}
\]

Given \(B(r) = B_0 \left( \frac{r}{r_0} \right)^n\),

\[
\frac{dB}{dr} = B_0 n \left( \frac{r}{r_0} \right)^{n-1} \frac{1}{r_0} = \frac{n B_0}{r_0} \left( \frac{r}{r_0} \right)^{n-1}
\]

At \(r = r_0\):

\[
\left. \frac{dB}{dr} \right|_{r_0} = \frac{n B_0}{r_0}
\]

From the equilibrium condition:

\[
q B_0 = - \frac{m v_0}{r_0}
\]

Thus:

\[
f'(r_0) = -\frac{m v_0^2}{r_0^2} + q v_0 \left( \frac{n B_0}{r_0} \right) = -\frac{m v_0^2}{r_0^2} + \left( - \frac{m v_0}{r_0} \right) \frac{n v_0}{r_0} = -\frac{m v_0^2}{r_0^2} - n \frac{m v_0^2}{r_0^2} = - (1 + n) \frac{m v_0^2}{r_0^2}
\]

The equation of motion becomes:

\[
m \ddot{\delta r} = f'(r_0) \delta r = - (1 + n) \frac{m v_0^2}{r_0^2} \delta r
\]

Simplifying:

\[
\ddot{\delta r} = - (1 + n) \frac{v_0^2}{r_0^2} \delta r
\]

This is the harmonic oscillator equation with angular frequency:

\[
\omega = \frac{v_0}{r_0} \sqrt{1 + n} = \frac{|q| B_0}{m} \sqrt{1 + n}
\]

The period of oscillation is:

\[
T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega} = \frac{2\pi m}{|q| B_0 \sqrt{1 + n}}
\]

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{T = \dfrac{2\pi m}{|q| B_{0} \sqrt{1 + n}}}
\]

questions: A regular dodecahedron resistor network is given. Except for $R_{BC} = 2r$, the resistance between all other adjacent vertices is $r$. Points $B$ and $C$ are the two endpoints of one edge of the dodecahedron. Find the resistance between points $B$ and $C$.
solutions:
Boldly introducing negative resistance, $BC$ is equivalent to a parallel combination of $\pmb{r}$ and $-2r$:  

$$
\frac{1}{r}+\frac{1}{-2r}=\frac{1}{2r}
$$

After extracting $-2r$, the remaining resistance value can be constructed using the forced current method. Inject $19I_{1}$ into node $B$, and each of the other nodes emits a current of 1. Then consider injecting $I$ into each of the other nodes while node $C$ emits $191$. Thus, the current flowing through the branch:  

$$
I_{BC}=20I
$$

Voltage:  

$$
U_{BC}=\frac{19Ir}{3}\cdot2
$$

Thus:  

$$
U_{BC}=I_{BC}R_{BC}^{\prime}
$$

Resulting in:  

$$
R_{BC}^{\prime}=\frac{19}{30}r
$$

Then, parallel it with $-2r$:  

$$
\frac{1}{R_{BC}}=\frac{1}{R_{BC}^{\prime}}+\frac{1}{-2r}
$$

Finally obtained:  

$$
R_{BC}=\frac{38}{41}r
$$

The resistance between vertices \(B\) and \(C\) in the dodecahedron resistor network, where the resistance between \(B\) and \(C\) is \(2r\) and all other adjacent vertices have resistance \(r\), is found by recognizing that the direct edge between \(B\) and \(C\) is in parallel with the subnetwork connecting \(B\) and \(C\) through all other paths. This subnetwork, denoted \(S\), is equivalent to the dodecahedron with the direct edge \(BC\) removed, and all resistances in \(S\) are \(r\).

The equivalent resistance \(R_S\) between \(B\) and \(C\) in subnetwork \(S\) is required. For a regular dodecahedron with all resistances \(r\), the equivalent resistance \(R_{\text{adj}}\) between two adjacent vertices is known to be \(\frac{11}{30}r\). This value accounts for the direct edge being present. When the direct edge is absent, the equivalent resistance \(R_S\) satisfies the relation:

\[
\frac{1}{R_{\text{adj}}} = \frac{1}{r} + \frac{1}{R_S}
\]

Substituting \(R_{\text{adj}} = \frac{11}{30}r\):

\[
\frac{1}{\frac{11}{30}r} = \frac{1}{r} + \frac{1}{R_S}
\]

Simplifying:

\[
\frac{30}{11r} = \frac{1}{r} + \frac{1}{R_S}
\]

Dividing both sides by \(r\):

\[
\frac{30}{11} = 1 + \frac{r}{R_S}
\]

Solving for \(\frac{r}{R_S}\):

\[
\frac{r}{R_S} = \frac{30}{11} - 1 = \frac{30}{11} - \frac{11}{11} = \frac{19}{11}
\]

Thus:

\[
R_S = \frac{11}{19}r
\]

In the original network, the direct edge with resistance \(2r\) is in parallel with the subnetwork \(S\) having resistance \(R_S = \frac{11}{19}r\). The equivalent resistance \(R_{\text{eq}}\) between \(B\) and \(C\) is given by:

\[
\frac{1}{R_{\text{eq}}}} = \frac{1}{2r} + \frac{1}{R_S} = \frac{1}{2r} + \frac{1}{\frac{11}{19}r} = \frac{1}{2r} + \frac{19}{11r}
\]

Combining the terms:

\[
\frac{1}{R_{\text{eq}}}} = \frac{1}{r} \left( \frac{1}{2} + \frac{19}{11} \right) = \frac{1}{r} \left( \frac{11}{22} + \frac{38}{22} \right) = \frac{1}{r} \left( \frac{49}{22} \right) = \frac{49}{22r}
\]

Therefore:

\[
R_{\text{eq}} = \frac{22r}{49}
\]

This result is consistent with the expected behavior: when the direct edge resistance is increased from \(r\) to \(2r\), the equivalent resistance increases from \(\frac{11}{30}r \approx 0.3667r\) to \(\frac{22}{49}r \approx 0.4489r\), which is greater than \(0.3667r\) but less than \(2r\), and also less than \(R_S = \frac{11}{19}r \approx 0.5789r\), as adding a conductor in parallel reduces the equivalent resistance.

### Final Answer
\[
\boxed{\dfrac{22r}{49}}
\]

questions: Consider a small cylindrical object with radius $R$ and height $h$. Determine the expression for the force $F$ acting on the cylinder when a sound wave passes through it. The axial direction of the cylinder is the direction of wave propagation. In the sound wave, the displacement of a particle from its equilibrium position is $\psi = A\cos kx\cos 2\pi ft$, the ambient pressure is $P_0$, and the adiabatic index of air is $\gamma$.
solutions:
The force on the cylinder will be  

$$
F = -\pi R^{2}(p(y+h)-p(y)) = -\pi R^{2}h\frac{d p}{d y}
$$  

For a traveling wave, substitute  

$$
\Delta p(y,t) = -\gamma p_{0}A k\cos(k y-2\pi f t)
$$  

$$
\frac{d p}{d y} = \gamma p_{0}A k^{2}\sin(k y-2\pi f t)
$$  

Therefore, the force is  

$$
F = -\pi R^2 h\gamma p_0 A k^2\sin(ky-2\pi ft)
$$

However, for a standing wave, we have  

$$
\psi = A\cos{k x}\cos{2\pi}f t
$$  

Thus,  

$$
\Delta p = \gamma P_{0}k A\sin k x\cos2\pi f t
$$  


Therefore,  

$$
\frac{d p}{d x} = \gamma P_{0}k^{2}A\cos k x\cos2\pi f t
$$  

Thus, the force is  

$$
F = -\pi R^2 h\gamma P_0 k^2 A\cos kx \cos 2\pi ft
$$
final_answers:
$$
F = -\pi R^2 h \gamma P_0 k^2 A \cos(kx) \cos(2\pi ft)
$$

The force acting on the cylinder is determined by the net force in the axial direction due to the pressure variation caused by the sound wave. Given the displacement \(\psi = A \cos(kx) \cos(2\pi f t)\), the excess pressure \(p\) in the sound wave is derived as follows.

The bulk modulus for an adiabatic process is \(B = \gamma P_0\). The pressure excess \(p\) is related to the displacement by \(p = -B \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial x}\). Differentiating the displacement:

\[
\frac{\partial \psi}{\partial x} = -A k \sin(kx) \cos(2\pi f t),
\]

so

\[
p = -\gamma P_0 \left(-A k \sin(kx) \cos(2\pi f t)\right) = \gamma P_0 A k \sin(kx) \cos(2\pi f t).
\]

The net force \(F(t)\) in the axial direction (x-direction) on the cylinder arises only from the pressure on the two end faces, as the curved surface contributes no net axial force due to symmetry. The force on the left end at \(x\) and the right end at \(x + h\) is:

\[
F(t) = \pi R^2 \left[ p(x + h, t) - p(x, t) \right],
\]

where \(\pi R^2\) is the cross-sectional area. Substituting the pressure expression:

\[
F(t) = \pi R^2 \left[ \gamma P_0 A k \sin(k(x + h)) \cos(2\pi f t) - \gamma P_0 A k \sin(kx) \cos(2\pi f t) \right].
\]

Simplifying the difference of sines:

\[
\sin(k(x + h)) - \sin(kx) = 2 \cos\left(kx + \frac{kh}{2}\right) \sin\left(\frac{kh}{2}\right),
\]

so

\[
F(t) = \pi R^2 \gamma P_0 A k \cos(2\pi f t) \cdot 2 \cos\left(kx + \frac{kh}{2}\right) \sin\left(\frac{kh}{2}\right) = 2 \pi R^2 \gamma P_0 A k \sin\left(\frac{kh}{2}\right) \cos\left(kx + \frac{kh}{2}\right) \cos(2\pi f t).
\]

For a small cylinder, where the dimensions are small compared to the wavelength (\(\lambda = 2\pi / k\), so \(kh \ll 1\) and \(kR \ll 1\)), approximations can be made. Using \(\sin(\theta) \approx \theta\) for small \(\theta\):

\[
\sin\left(\frac{kh}{2}\right) \approx \frac{kh}{2}.
\]

Also, \(\cos(kx + kh/2) \approx \cos(kx)\) since \(kh/2 \ll 1\). Thus:

\[
F(t) \approx 2 \pi R^2 \gamma P_0 A k \left(\frac{kh}{2}\right) \cos(kx) \cos(2\pi f t) = \pi R^2 h \gamma P_0 A k^2 \cos(kx) \cos(2\pi f t).
\]

The center of the cylinder is at \(x_c = x + h/2\). For small \(h\), \(x \approx x_c\), so \(\cos(kx) \approx \cos(k x_c)\). The displacement at the center is \(\psi_{\text{c}}(t) = A \cos(k x_c) \cos(2\pi f t)\), so:

\[
F(t) \approx \pi R^2 h \gamma P_0 k^2 \psi_{\text{c}}(t),
\]

where \(\psi_{\text{c}}(t)\) is the particle displacement of the sound wave at the center of the cylinder.

This expression is valid for a small cylinder (\(kh \ll 1\) and \(kR \ll 1\)), and it shows that the net axial force is proportional to the volume \(\pi R^2 h\) and the local displacement at the center.

### Final Answer
\[ \boxed{F(t) = \pi R^{2} h \gamma P_{0} k^{2} \psi_{\text{c}}(t)} \]

In certain solids, ions have spin angular momentum and can be regarded as a three-dimensional real vector $\vec{S}$ with a fixed length under the semiclassical approximation, where the length $\vert\vec{S}\vert = S$ is a constant. The magnetic moment $\overrightarrow{M}$ of the ions is usually proportional to the spin vector, ${\overrightarrow{M}} = \gamma{\overrightarrow{S}}$, where $\gamma(>0)$ is a constant. The spin-spin interaction between ions $i$ and $j$ is usually the Heisenberg interaction, $-J_{i,j}\vec{S}_{i} \cdot \vec{S}_{j}$. Under a static uniform external magnetic field $\overrightarrow{B}$, the total energy (Hamiltonian) of the system is typically given by $\begin{array}{r}{H = -\sum_{(i,j)}J_{i,j}\vec{S}_{i}\cdot\vec{S}_{j} - }\end{array}$ $\begin{array}{r}{\gamma\overrightarrow{B}\cdot\sum_{i}\overrightarrow{S}_{i}}\end{array}$. Here, $(i,j)$ indicates a sum over all distinct pairs without order, meaning $(i,j)$ and $(j,i)$ represent the same pair and are not counted twice. The semiclassical time evolution of the spin vector satisfies the Heisenberg equation of motion (here $\times{}$ represents the vector cross product):
$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{i}=\frac{\partial H}{\partial \vec{S}_{i}}\times\vec{S}_{i}
$$
Consider two spins, $H = -J\vec{S}_{1}\cdot\vec{S}_{2} - \gamma\vec{B}\cdot\left(\vec{S}_{1}+\vec{S}_{2}\right)$, where $J>0$. Without loss of generality, let $\overrightarrow{B}$ be along the $\mathbf{Z}$ direction, $\vec{B}=B\hat{\bf z}$, $B \geq 0$. The ground state (lowest energy state) of the system is $\vec{S}_{1}=\vec{S}_{2}=S\hat{\mathbf{z}}$, and this state does not evolve over time. Consider states close to the ground state, $\vec{S}_{1}=S\big(x_{1},y_{1},\sqrt{1-{x_{1}}^{2}-{y_{1}}^{2}}\big)$, $\vec{S}_{2}=S\big(x_{2},y_{2},\sqrt{1-{x_{2}}^{2}-{y_{2}}^{2}}\big)$, where $\left|x_{1,2}\right|\ll1, \left|y_{1,2}\right|\ll1$. Find the product of the final normal mode frequencies.
solutions:
Solution: The Heisenberg equation of motion is
$$
\begin{array}{r}{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{1}=-\left(J\vec{S}_{2}+\gamma\vec{B}\right)\times\vec{S}_{1}}\ {\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{2}=-\left(J\vec{S}_{1}+\gamma\vec{B}\right)\times\vec{S}_{2}}\end{array}
$$
Note that $\vec{S}_{\pm}=\vec{S}_{1}\pm\vec{S}_{2}$ can be defined, then $\begin{array}{r}{H=\frac{J}{2}\big|\overrightarrow{S}_{+}\big|^{2}-J S^{2}-\gamma\overrightarrow{B}\cdot\overrightarrow{S}_{+}}\end{array}$,
$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{+}=-\gamma\vec{B}\times\vec{S}_{+}
$$
$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\vec{S}_{-}=-\left(\vec{J S}_{+}+\gamma\vec{B}\right)\times\vec{S}_{-}
$$
The equations of motion for $x_{1,2},y_{1,2}$ in the lowest order approximation are
$$
\begin{array}{c}{{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(x_{1}+x_{2})=\gamma B\cdot(y_{1}+y_{2})}}\ {{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(y_{1}+y_{2})=-\gamma B\cdot(x_{1}+x_{2})}}\ {{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(x_{1}-x_{2})\approx(2J S+\gamma B)\cdot(y_{1}-y_{2})}}\ {{\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(y_{1}-y_{2})\approx-(2J S+\gamma B)\cdot(x_{1}-x_{2})}}\end{array}
$$
The product of the characteristic frequencies is
$\gamma B(2J S+\gamma B)$
